About species evolution, If humans evolved from monkeys, why are there still monkeys here?

 Humans didn't evolve from monkeys. Humans and monkeys and other primates share an ancestor. Even if they did, species can (and often do) break up into groups where some groups evolve more rapidly or change more extremely than others. A species doesn't have to die out for some of them to evolve.

If we were born from slime, why are there still not humans being created this same way?

 We aren't born from slime, and no humans have even been created fully-grown from slime. Creatures have evolved from "slime" to become other creatures, who became other creatures, etc., until you got to mammals and primates and humans. 
 
 
 Regarding the survival of the fittest, humans seem to be exempt from this process. We have always cared for the weakest members of our society, not destroyed them.

 Fittest doesn't mean strongest. It means "most fitting", in other words, "most well-adapted". Therefore, if being a big and strong creature is a good adaptation in your environment, being big and strong is "fitting". Conversely, if being small and quick is adaptive, than that is fitting. This is where ecological "niches" come into it. 
 
 The giraffe is a good example. The giraffe-ancestors with the longest necks always got the most food because noone else around was that tall. So, the longest-necked giraffe-ancestors lived longer, were healthier, and reproduced more. As time went on, the long-necked giraffe-ancestors outnumbered their shorter-necked peers, and this trend continued. A giraffe's neck at this point is disproportionately long and thin- this could be seen as a weakness (and would be in some environments). However, the circumstances of the giraffe-ancestors were such that having an extremely long neck was advantageous, so that characteristic has survived.

 I've talked with other posters about the issue of personal bias in science. There's no doubt that it exists, despite the scientific ideals that would remove it. 
 
 I think we're dealing with different levels of "reality" here as well. Abiogenesis, the Big Bang, and other theories are still very abstract in their definitions and processes. The data we have is not sufficient or concise enough to allow any definite conclusions to be drawn, they're theories, and in many ways, still completely open to debate and research. However, there is a common thread in it, the data that is there. That data requires explanation and understanding.
 
 I'm a petroleum geologist by training, so let's deal with geology. To be a creationist, you must dismiss geology. You can argue that you don't have to dismiss geology as the "science of studying the origin, history and structure of the Earth", only the conclusions of MOST geologists, but I would argue that is simply an unrealistic assertion.
 
 For sure there is a lot of disagreement within the geological community when it comes to conclusions drawn about detailed geological formations/structures/mechanisms/timing/etc..., geology is in many ways a "soft science" as we are unable to turn back the clock or dig up miles of rock inch by inch. However, when it comes to the main tenets of geology that would contradict a young earth Creationist's time frame, agreement among the geological community would be nearly unanimous. Those that object would have to do so based on preconceived notions, not the data before them, at least IMHO. 
 
 I think this is the case for most sciences. The data is there. If A,B,C,D and E all lead toward conclusion F, it's hard to justify conclusion Z based solely on A, or on G. 
 
 In this manner, I think to reject some or all of the conclusions of many or all of the sciences I mentioned means to dismiss them entirely, or to so distort them that they aren't in fact realistic depictions of the science anymore. 
 
 The analogy would be to pick and chose only certain passages from the Bible. Doing so would allow a person to justify almost any action imaginable, that doesn't mean that the Bible supports that action, or that the justification is correct according to the Bible.

 Well, you are very incorrect when you say that Evolution violates the law of thermodynamics. # The second law of thermodynamics says no such thing. It says heat will not spontaneously flow from a colder body to a warmer one, or equivalently, that total entropy (a measure of useful energy) in a closed system will not decrease. This doesn't prevent increasing order because
 
 * the earth is not a closed system; sunlight (with low entropy) shines on it and heat (with higher entropy) radiates off. This flow of energy, and the change in entropy which accompanies it, can and will power local decreases in entropy on earth.
 * entropy is not the same as disorder. Sometimes the two correspond, but sometimes order increases as entropy increases. [Aranda-Espinoza et al. 1999; Kestenbaum 1998] Entropy can even be used to produce order, such as in the sorting of molecules by size [Han and Craighead 2000].
 * even in a closed system, pockets of lower entropy can form if they are offset by increased entropy elsewhere in the system. 
 
 In short, order from disorder happens on earth all the time.
